author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Goldilocks Came to the U.S. Economy
description: The optimists were right. But why?
content: Early this year many economists held a very grim view about the prospects for reducing inflation without a major economic slowdown and a big rise in unemployment. One prominent economist declared that underlying inflation was at least 4.5 percent and that “all the hoped-for saviors” — that is, forces that might bring inflation down painlessly — “have come and gone.” Inflation, another declared, would be “sticky around 4 to 5 percent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: ‘It Is Evening, Isn’t It?’ An 80-Year-Old President’s Whirlwind Trip.
description: President Biden went to Asia with a diplomatic to-do list. But he also wanted to show he remains up to the rigors of globe-trotting statesmanship.
content: On the 13th hour of the third day of a two-country trip, President Biden stepped onstage at a news conference in Vietnam and bid reporters there a good evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: As Ukraine Aid Benefits Their Districts, Some House Republicans Oppose It
description: The American push to fund Kyiv’s war effort has created big economic opportunities for Mesquite, Texas, and other cities around the country. Some of their G.O.P. congressmen want to end it.
content: By early next year, this city best known for being the rodeo capital of Texas is on track to become a centerpiece of the American effort to increase artillery production vital to the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Putting Women at the Center of Human Evolution
description: Cat Bohannon’s book, “Eve,” looks at the way women’s bodies evolved, and how a focus on male subjects in science has left women “under-studied and under-cared for.”
content: The author Cat Bohannon was a preteen in Atlanta in the 1980s when she saw the film “2001: A Space Odyssey” for the first time. As she took in its famous opening scene, in which a bunch of apes picks up a bunch of bones and quickly begins using them to hit each other, Bohannon was struck by the sheer maleness of the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of Sept. 4, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Drew Barrymore’s Show Is Picketed as It Resumes Amid Writers’ Strike
description: The star, who dropped out of an MTV awards show in May to demonstrate solidarity with striking writers, plans to bring her daytime talk show back without its unionized writers.
content: When Drew Barrymore announced in May that she was stepping down as host of the MTV Movie & TV Awards to show solidarity with striking Hollywood writers, she received an outpouring of praise from fans and viewers who supported her stance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: A Q&A With Elon Musk’s Biographer
description: Walter Isaacson said he wrestled with the competing identities of a brilliant but “mercurial” entrepreneur.
content: For two years, Walter Isaacson embedded himself with Elon Musk to research his biography of the world’s richest man. Revelations from the book, which will be released on Tuesday, have already generated headlines: the psychological scars Mr. Musk carries from the way his father treated him as a child; his decision to limit Ukrainian access to the Starlink satellite network to prevent military operations; and his last-minute move to fire Twitter’s top executives before their stock options could vest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Could Be the Jets’ Year, Fireman Ed Says
description: A superfan, he thinks Aaron Rodgers will give the team momentum. He’ll be in the stands, leading cheers.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out why someone whom Jets fans know as Fireman Ed will be on duty, so to speak, at MetLife Stadium tonight. We’ll also catch up with the swimmer who has almost finished his monthlong trip down the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
description: The updated vaccines could become available within a few days.
content: Two new Covid shots have received the green light from the Food and Drug Administration. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is expected to follow up with guidance on eligibility as soon as Tuesday, making the new vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna available as Covid cases continue to rise in some parts of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Valeriya Safronova
title: Kim Jong-un Has Something Putin Needs, and That’s a New Wrinkle
description: Kim Jong-un has ammunition stocks that Russia covets as it continues its war in Ukraine, and North Korea may get advanced technology and badly needed food aid in return.
content: When North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, visited President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia four years ago, it was mostly for diplomatic show.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 11, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 11, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Robin Roberts and Amber Laign Speak ‘Freely, Openly and Passionately’ About Their Love
description: The couple were wed Sept. 8 in an intimate ceremony at their home in Farmington, Conn. The newlyweds spoke to The New York Times in an exclusive interview about their relationship.
content: On a recent Thursday morning, after ABC’s “Good Morning America” had finished its broadcast, Robin Rene Roberts and Amber Laign sat in the corner table of a restaurant a couple hundred feet away from the studio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion Tribes of New York
description: Ralph Lauren, Coach, Proenza Schouler and Khaite: Recognize your camouflage?
content: It’s been a while since New York was the main character in any costume drama, a while since it starred as anything other than a problem: abandoned, messy, crime-ridden, economically challenged. But as New York Fashion Week began, the city’s designers were telling a different story. One about the city as a place of chaos, movement and dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Hiker Spotted on Bear Cam Rescued From Alaskan Wilderness
description: Viewers alerted the authorities after a hiker who appeared cold and drenched looked into a wildlife webcam and asked for help.
content: The live video feed of a lush Alaskan hillside and brown bears bathing in a river at Dumpling Mountain in Katmai National Park and Preserve became obscured by a dense screen of fog, followed by a particularly alarming sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden’s News Conference in Vietnam Ignites His Opponents
description: The president’s top aides believe that stories about the president’s age and health are stoked by his enemies in an effort to undermine his accomplishments.
content: In three days of diplomacy in Asia, President Biden rallied world leaders to help finance poor nations, fortified the coalition backing Ukraine and struck a deal with Vietnam to counter Chinese aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Claims to Have Retaken Oil and Gas Platforms in the Black Sea
description: The platforms have played a role in Russia’s ability to project power off Ukraine’s coast since Moscow seized them in 2015.
content: Ukraine said on Monday that it had taken control of several oil and gas platforms in the Black Sea, after a series of clashes with Russian aerial and maritime forces in the waters between Odesa and the occupied Crimean Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer
title: As Democratic Jitters Grow, Biden Campaign Tries to Showcase His Vigor
description: With low approval ratings and shaky public performances, the president and his team are planning an ad blitz and trying to reassure voters about his age.
content: With stubbornly subterranean approval numbers, President Biden is taking early steps to shore up his re-election candidacy with a multipronged strategy that includes a costly advertising campaign and leveraging the powers of the bully pulpit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Nico Grant
title: Why Is the Justice Dept. Suing Google?
description: The government claims that Google illegally used its monopoly power to stifle rivals, while the company says its practices are legal and mainstream.
content: A federal judge will start hearing claims this week from the Justice Department and a group of states that Google abused its power as a monopoly over online search services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Museum at FIT Explores the Intersection of Food and Fashion
description: Check out new vegetable varieties from Dan Barber’s Row 7, pick up a round braided challah for the holiday and more food news.
content: “Food & Fashion” — an exhibit at FIT’s museum that coincides with Fashion Week — begins with a gallery that shows food themes in fashion then moves into a space designed like a food hall with stalls that explore how food and dining have dictated fashion from the 18th century forward. There is also a display that illustrate the intersection of food and art in fashion, and how fashion depicts foods, like Issey Miyake’s accessories made to look like sushi and Judith Leiber’s tomato minaudière. Sweets and femininity, fashion and its relationship to issues like activism and sustainability, and how the fashionable body dictates food choices are also explored. The exhibit was organized by Melissa Marra-Alvarez, the museum’s curator of education and research, and Elizabeth Way, an associate curator of costume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: 13 Years Later, Construction to Restart on Hudson River Rail Tunnel
description: As soon as next month, work could begin on the first steps to create a two-track tunnel at the center of the Gateway project.
content: After a 13-year detour, work is about to begin again in New Jersey on a rail tunnel that would run all the way to Midtown Manhattan and end the region’s reliance on a pair of crumbling tubes built more than a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush
title: Contractor for U.S. Government Charged With Spying for Ethiopia, Officials Say
description: The connection of the contractor to Ethiopia, a country that is a significant recipient of aid from the United States, is unusual.
content: A contractor who has worked for the State and Justice Departments has been arrested and charged with spying for Ethiopia, according to several U.S. officials with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Mounting casualties in Morocco.
content: A powerful earthquake struck Morocco on Friday night, killing more than 2,100 people and setting off frantic rescue efforts in rubble-strewn city streets and remote rural areas, as some residents sifted through mountains of debris with their bare hands. The next days are critical: After four or five days, the possibility of survival dwindles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Restaurants and Unions Agree to Raise Pay to $20 an Hour in California
description: The deal will avoid a ballot fight over a law passed last year that could have resulted in higher pay and other changes opposed by restaurant companies and franchisees.
content: Labor groups and fast-food companies in California reached an agreement over the weekend that will pave the way for workers in the industry to receive a minimum wage of $20 per hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad and Catherine Porter
title: A Diver Feared the Titan Sub, but Couldn’t Resist the Titanic
description: Paul-Henri Nargeolet mixed decades of passion for the ship of dreams with repeated dives and recoveries meant to save what remained of the famous ocean liner.
content: A riddle haunts the Titan disaster. It’s the presence on the doomed craft of Paul-Henri Nargeolet, 77. The Frenchman was one of the world’s great submariners. So why was he, of all people, diving repeatedly to the Titanic on a submersible that many experts saw as a catastrophe waiting to happen?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Jamila Woods’s Songs Have Many Loves
description: “Water Made Us,” a new album due Oct. 13, achieves the musician’s greatest synthesis yet between her voices as a poet and as a songwriter.
content: For many artists, the weeks leading up to a new album are a hectic flurry of promotional obligations, relentless tour rehearsals and omnipresent anxiety. But two months before the Oct. 13 release of Jamila Woods’s “Water Made Us,” the Chicago-based writer and musician was far from the music industry’s antic churn: at a six-week writing residency at a remote castle in Umbria, Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: ‘Virginia Is the Test Case’: Youngkin Pushes for G.O.P. Takeover This Fall
description: Glenn Youngkin, a popular Republican governor with national ambitions, is trying to help his party take full control of state government in crucial legislative races this year.
content: Virginia, whose off-year elections are usually closely watched as an indicator of the national mood, has been mostly out of the spotlight this year, overshadowed by the Republican presidential primary and the looming general election clash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dale Russakoff
title: Is School Choice Destroying Public Education?
description: In a new book, Cara Fitzpatrick traces the rise of the movement to expand public funding for privately operated institutions.
content: Cara Fitzpatrick’s first book,“The Death of Public School,” opens with a superb survey of the political, cultural, legal and natural forces undermining public trust in our nation’s schools. The terrible disruption of the pandemic. The Republican-fueled culture wars over gender and race in the curriculum. The decades-long conservative campaign to legalize private school vouchers, capped by last year’s Supreme Court ruling that parents must be allowed to spend those vouchers at religious as well as secular schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Israelis Have Been Protesting for Months. Now, Americans Are Joining Them.
description: American Jews have been reluctant to join in demonstrations against Israel’s plans to overhaul its judiciary, but some are overcoming their resistance.
content: For months, Beth Levine, an attorney in New York, grew worried about developments in Israel, where the far-right government has sought to diminish the judicial branch’s independence. Its efforts provoked massive protests in Israel and smaller ones in the United States, including most Sundays in Manhattan’s Washington Square Park. Though sympathetic to the cause, Ms. Levine, who lives in the Bronx, never attended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Jackie Frere
title: Getting to Genius, Part 2: Becoming Queen Bee
description: How to use the game’s tools and the “Hivemind” to your advantage.
content: This is Part 2 of a two-part series on learning to solve Spelling Bee. Be sure to check out Part 1.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mayor Adams and the Migrant Crisis in New York
description: Responses to Mayor Eric Adams’s remarks about the migrant influx. Also: President Biden’s silence on the Trump indictments; football; pornography; plastics.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Trump’s Electoral College Edge Seems to Be Fading
description: Democrats appear resilient in the battleground states despite a nationwide loss of nonwhite support. New issues may be one reason.
content: The early polls show Donald J. Trump and President Biden tied nationwide. Does that mean Mr. Trump has a clear advantage in the battleground states that decide the Electoral College?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Once Again You Lose Me at the Wall
description: The wall isn’t very useful at stopping migrants, but it’s great as a symbol of our worst impulses.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Democratic mayors and governors are warning the Biden administration that the migrants crossing our southern border are straining their cities and states to the breaking point. New York City alone is sheltering and feeding an average of 59,000 migrants a day. What’s your advice to the White House?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Inside Los Angeles’s Fraught Redistricting Process
description: A conversation with Jill Cowan, who spent months reporting on how members of the City Council redrew political maps to largely maintain their power.
content: You may remember the explosive recording of Los Angeles City Council members that was leaked last year. The profanity-laced audio, in which L.A. leaders can be heard mocking people in racist terms, stunned the city and prompted several high-profile resignations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Approves New Covid Shots
description: A nationwide rollout of the vaccines by Pfizer and Moderna should begin later this week, after the C.D.C. considers guidelines to prepare Americans for this season when infections usually tick upward.
content: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new round of Covid boosters on Monday, that will arrive alongside the seasonal flu vaccine and shots to protect infants and older adults from R.S.V., a potentially lethal respiratory virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Fiber Art Is Finally Being Taken Seriously
description: Long caught in the liminal space between craft and something more prestigious, works of thread and fabric are reaching newfound institutional recognition.
content: IN FEBRUARY OF 1969, by a first-floor window that looked out on 53rd Street, the Museum of Modern Art in New York installed a work by a then-34-year-old artist named Sheila Hicks called “The Evolving Tapestry: He/She” (1967-68). Made of more than 3,000 “ponytails” of linen thread, as the artist called them, stitched together and piled atop one another, it looked at first glance like something one might encounter in a commercial fabric store. Neither traditional sculpture nor painting, it conjured both, a monumental object made from the humblest materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McCarthy Is Under the Gun as the House Returns for a Spending Fight
description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy faces his biggest test since the debt ceiling showdown as right-wing Republicans demand deep spending cuts and tougher border policies opposed by the White House and Senate.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s job is on the line as the House returns on Tuesday to confront a funding impasse that could lead to a government shutdown or a challenge to the California Republican’s hold on the top post in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Who’s Who in the Google Monopoly Trial
description: The federal government’s first monopoly trial this century will feature top tech executives, experienced litigators and an Obama-appointed judge.
content: A trial to determine if Google abused its monopoly in online search, which begins on Tuesday, is set to lay bare how the internet search giant cemented its power, featuring testimony from top tech executives, engineers, economists and academics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: As Smartphone Industry Sputters, the iPhone Expands Its Dominance
description: Apple, which is set to release a new iPhone on Tuesday, has increased its share of smartphone sales by converting Android customers and adding teenagers.
content: There’s a general rule about consumer electronics: The older a device becomes, the more competitors appear and prices fall. This was true for televisions, personal computers and portable music players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Somber 9/11 Ceremony Draws Mourners to Ground Zero
description: Relatives of those who died went to Lower Manhattan to mark the 22nd anniversary of the terrorist attack, where they were joined by governors, senators and the vice president.
content: Mourners gathered in grief in Lower Manhattan on Monday, hugging each other and fighting back tears as they commemorated their lost loved ones on the 22nd anniversary of Sept. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Microsoft, Google and Antitrust: Similar Legal Theories in a Different Era
description: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
content: The Justice Department argues in a federal antitrust suit that Google is a dominant tech company that has abused its market power to bully industry partners, protect its monopoly and thwart competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Sanity Question and Plea Talks Shadow Coming Sept. 11 Hearings
description: Prosecutors issued a new deadline of next week on their offer to have the defendants plead guilty and avoid a capital trial.
content: Prosecutors have issued a new deadline — Sept. 18 — for four detainees at the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to show their willingness to plead guilty to plotting the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and receive a maximum punishment of life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: A Party for Steven Meisel, Without Steven Meisel
description: The fashion world came out to honor the star photographer. He didn’t show.
content: At a cocktail party in Lower Manhattan on Friday to celebrate a new collection of clothing and accessories designed by the fashion photographer Steven Meisel for Zara, practically the only boldface name who didn’t show up was Steven Meisel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher, Chris Buckley and Tripp Mickle
title: Chinese Warnings on iPhones Tap Deep Strain of Security Concerns
description: For years, officials in China have been told to shun foreign devices. Now reports of renewed curbs have unnerved Apple’s investors, heightening geopolitical tensions.
content: China has discouraged the use of foreign-made electronic devices by government officials for a decade. It has told agencies and state-owned companies to replace American computer servers and other devices with domestic ones. And officials frequently show off to Americans their phones made by Huawei, China’s cellphone giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Island Nations Hope for Court’s Help on Climate’s Effects
description: A tribunal is expected to issue an advisory opinion on behalf of Pacific and Caribbean countries on whether greenhouse gases are pollutants that violate international law.
content: A group of small island nations threatened by frequent storms and rising seas is for the first time appearing before an international court to seek its help, hoping for a decision that excessive greenhouse gases are pollutants that violate international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This One-Pot Orzo With Bacon Uses a Clever Corn Trick
description: Don’t slice your kernels. Grate them instead for this creamy, extra-corny dinner that’s ready in less than an hour.
content: I thought I’d tried every way there was to cut the kernels off an ear of corn. I braced the ears in a Bundt pan and sunk them into a deep bowl; I held them horizontally and I held them vertically. I even tested out some of those single-task corn-slicing tools, none of which did any better than a cutting board and a knife. But until I saw Samantha Seneviratne’s new recipe for creamy one-pot orzo with corn and bacon, it had never occurred to me to pull out the box grater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Met Commissions an Opera About Abducted Ukrainian Children
description: The work, by the Ukrainian composer Maxim Kolomiiets and the American playwright George Brant, is inspired by the accounts of mothers whose children were taken during the war.
content: The Metropolitan Opera announced Monday that it had commissioned a new opera about Russia’s abduction and deportation of thousands of Ukrainian children, the latest action by the company to show support for war-torn Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China May Ban Clothes That Hurt People’s Feelings. People Are Outraged.
description: A proposal evokes memories of 1980s China, when opening up to the world set off a debate over flared pants and men with long hair, what the party called “weird attire.”
content: In the 1980s, people in China could land themselves in trouble with the government for their fashion choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohammed Abdusamee and Isabella Kwai
title: Hundreds Reported Dead in Severe Libya Flooding
description: The waters swept away hundreds of homes as emergency officials raced to find survivors of the flooding caused by torrential weekend rains. Officials in one city described “catastrophic” devastation.
content: Deadly floods swept through northeastern Libya over the weekend, with the top official in the region warning that the toll could exceed 2,000 dead as rescue teams searched for survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto and Safak Timur
title: American Cave Expert Is Rescued in Turkey
description: Mark Dickey became sick deep underground more than a week ago. His safe extraction brought together cavers from around the world.
content: An American cave expert who became ill while he was more than 3,000 feet underground in a cave in Turkey, prompting an international rescue effort, was pulled safely from the cave soon after midnight Tuesday morning local time and immediately brought to a medical tent, the Speleological Federation of Turkey announced in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Biden, Who Neither Fought in Vietnam Nor Protested War, Trip Offered Opportunity
description: While others of his generation were scarred by the conflict, President Biden forged a strategic partnership on his first visit to the country, framing it in pragmatic terms.
content: As he wrapped up a two-day trip to Hanoi, his first visit to Vietnam, President Biden on Monday made a point of stopping by a memorial to his old friend, Senator John McCain, the famed prisoner of war who was later instrumental in forging reconciliation with a onetime enemy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In J.M. Coetzee’s New Novel, Love Awakens an Austere Soul
description: “The Pole” explores romance, mortality and the tangled ways we communicate.
content: The South African writer J.M. Coetzee’s novels are slim, and so, by and large, are his characters — they’re Modiglianis, not Boteros. The most wraithlike, a saintly hunger artist, is the protagonist of his novel “The Life and Times of Michael K,” which won the Booker Prize in 1983.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Would You Want an A.I. Tutor?
description: Schools are experimenting with new automated teaching aids. Would you welcome a chatbot in your own classroom?
content: Do you get enough one-on-one attention from your teachers? Have you ever wished you had more access to tutors — in or outside the classroom? Would you ever want an A.I.-enhanced chatbot as a tutor or coach? Why, or why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Horrible Loss for the Giants, but Not the Worst Ever
description: The Giants were embarrassed at home by the Dallas Cowboys in a 40-0 laugher that was among the worst season openers in N.F.L. history. But all hope is not lost.
content: The Giants got the kickoff at home on Sunday night and advanced to the Dallas Cowboys’ 8-yard line in nine plays. What a start to the season!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Rachel McAdams to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Mary Jane’
description: The play, by Amy Herzog, is about a mother caring for a chronically ill child.
content: The film star Rachel McAdams will make her Broadway debut next spring in an acclaimed and heart-wrenching play about a mother caring for a small child with a serious illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Buchanan
title: Joey Votto Is Finally Ready to Meet You
description: In the 17th season of a Hall of Fame-worthy career, Votto has made the unusual shift from meticulous hitting savant to social media star.
content: On a July night in Milwaukee, Joey Votto got his revenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vidya Krishnan
title: Global Health’s Dirty Secret: Rich Countries Get Good Medicine, and the Poor Sometimes Get Poison
description: A chaotic system for regulating drugs leaves the world exposed to the next pandemic.
content: In April, a pregnant woman died at a hospital in Kandy, Sri Lanka, of complications blamed on an anesthetic manufactured in India. A few months earlier, Indian-made cough syrups were linked to the deaths of children in Gambia and Uzbekistan. Substandard medicines also were found this year in the Marshall Islands and Micronesia before they could do any harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Djokovic Honors Kobe Bryant With ‘Mamba Forever’ Shirt
description: Bryant, the N.B.A. star who died in a helicopter crash in 2020, was known for using No. 24 as one of his jersey numbers while playing for the Los Angeles Lakers.
content: Moments after Novak Djokovic won the U.S. Open men’s singles final on Sunday night, he pulled a T-shirt out his bag and put it on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro, Asmaa Elkeurti and Maansi Srivastava
title: How Soaring Child Care Costs Are Crushing New Yorkers
description: As the city’s affordability crisis worsens for nearly everyone, even upper-middle-class New Yorkers are struggling to pay for child care. The workers who provide it are struggling too.
content: Not long after Crystal Springs started her new job at a large insurance company in Midtown Manhattan earlier this year, she realized that a much bigger chunk of her paycheck than she expected was going directly to child care for her 5-year-old daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: With Straws, Gourds and Tea in Tow, Syrians Spread Their Love of mate
description: The strong, grassy South American tea was popular in Syria even before the war began there 12 years ago. As millions of people were internally displaced, they shared it around the country.
content: Since Walaa Ali first fled her home in central Syria nearly 10 years ago, she has moved around the country four times, seeking safety for her family. Each time she settled in a new place, she spread the word about mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Feinstein Battle Over Her Late Husband’s Fortune Heads to Mediation
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, 90, and her daughter are locked in a dispute with her late husband’s family over how to manage the assets of his vast estate.
content: A judge in San Francisco on Monday ordered the two factions of Senator Dianne Feinstein’s family fighting over the estate of her late husband, the wealthy financier Richard C. Blum, to try to settle the case through mediation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Governor Youngkin Pardons Father Who Was Arrested in School Board Meeting
description: In a Loudoun County, Va., case that became a national flashpoint over transgender rights, Scott Smith rose to accuse a boy of assaulting his daughter, and a fight ensued.
content: In a case that became a national flashpoint over transgender rights in schools, Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia has pardoned a father who was arrested during a contentious school board meeting in Loudoun County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Aid Trickles In to Morocco
description: Also, a Q&A with Elon Musk’s biographer.
content: As the death toll from the earthquake rose to at least 2,862 and many settlements waited desperately for help, a senior Moroccan official insisted that the authorities had promptly addressed the disaster amid public criticism over the pace of aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Austin Walsh
title: Elon Musk Has Crossed a Line
description: A consistent booster of far-right and antisemitic accounts on Twitter, Elon Musk is now melding a sense of victimhood with the most toxic elements of the right.
content: Elon Musk, one of the world’s richest men who is now most famous for running the website X, formerly known as Twitter, has a new excuse for the company’s shaky performance since he bought it last year. The problem, according to Mr. Musk, is the Jews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Red Cross Blames Climate Disasters for Blood Shortage
description: The supply in the United States has fallen nearly 25 percent since early August, the organization said.
content: The blood supply in the United States has dropped to critically low levels, in part because of “back-to-back months of worsening climate-related disasters,” the American Red Cross said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Shane
title: How the Underground Railroad Got Its Name
description: The Underground Railroad got its name from the most fascinating and important African American activist and writer you’ve never heard of.
content: Thomas Smallwood was a busy man in the summer of 1842. Born into slavery outside Washington, D.C., in 1801, he had largely educated himself and bought his own freedom 11 years before. By day, he ran a shoemaking business from the little house he shared with his wife and four children a short walk from the U.S. Capitol. By night, he was organizing daring, dangerous escapes from slavery — not by ones and twos but by the wagonload — from Washington, Baltimore and the surrounding counties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Rubiales Quits, but Women’s Soccer in Spain Is Still Troubled
description: After the resignation of the country’s soccer chief, recriminations, accusations and an inquiry remain.
content: After three weeks of protests and calls for his resignation, Spain’s soccer chief, Luis Rubiales, has quit, but the problems that surfaced in the wake of his forcible kiss of a player after the Women’s World Cup remain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Federal Court Says Consumer Watchdog Can’t Check Banks for Discrimination
description: A Texas judge’s sweeping ruling says the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau exceeded its authority in trying to examine banks for uneven treatment.
content: A federal judge in Texas ruled that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is overstepping its bounds in its attempts to check whether banks and other financial firms are discriminating against Black Americans and other minorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Unfinished Pursuit of a Better Poverty Measure
description: The official poverty measure is widely disliked, but experts may never agree on how to perfect it.
content: On Tuesday the Census Bureau is scheduled to release income and poverty statistics for 2022. It’s safe to say that the report will be hard to interpret. Last year, the two poverty measures released by the bureau pointed in opposite directions. One showed that poverty increased slightly in 2021, while the other showed it declined markedly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Disney and Charter Reach Agreement, Ending Cable Standoff
description: The impasse between the two companies had raised questions about the future of the cable bundle.
content: Disney and Charter said Monday that they had reached a deal to resolve their programming dispute, ending a skirmish that raised questions about the future of cable television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.4 Million Homes in California
description: A Gregory Ain-designed house in Altadena, a mountain retreat in Tahoma and a midcentury-modern escape in Palm Springs.
content: This is one of 28 houses in the Park Planned Homes development, an early midcentury-modern tract of homes near the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains. Gregory Ain, the architect, and Garrett Eckbo, the landscape architect, created a plan that promoted visual continuity by eliminating fences in front of the homes and using glass walls to divide interior spaces from the courtyards outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Tardiff
title: Nelia Sancho, Beauty Queen Turned Defiant Rights Activist, Dies at 71
description: She had been competing in pageants in the Philippines, but she found her calling when she observed the offenses of the Marcos regime firsthand.
content: Nelia Sancho was a 22-year-old student at the University of the Philippines when she witnessed something no student should see: Two of her professors were shot point-blank by government agents in front of her. They had been considered enemies of the state by the despotic regime of President Ferdinand Marcos for their involvement in the Communist Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Authors of ‘How Democracies Die’ Overestimated the Republicans
description: In a new book, they grapple with why Trump turned out to be even worse than they expected.
content: One of the most influential books of the Trump years was “How Democracies Die” by the Harvard government professors Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt. Published in 2018, it served as a guide to our unfolding ordeal. “Over the past two years, we have watched politicians say and do things that are unprecedented in the United States — but that we recognize as having been the precursors of democratic crisis in other places,” they wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Lee Myers
title: China Sows Disinformation About Hawaii Fires Using New Techniques
description: Beijing’s influence campaign using artificial intelligence is a rapid change in tactics, researchers from Microsoft and other organizations say.
content: When wildfires swept across Maui last month with destructive fury, China’s increasingly resourceful information warriors pounced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Kilauea, Hawaii’s Most Active Volcano, Erupts Again
description: The volcano, located on the Big Island, last erupted in June. The Hawaiian Volcano Observatory said there was no immediate threat to people or property.
content: Kilauea, Hawaii’s most active volcano, erupted for the second time in three months on Sunday afternoon, according to the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, which said there was no immediate danger to residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Sarah Burton Exits Alexander McQueen
description: The British designer and successor to Mr. McQueen will leave the label she has led for 13 years after one last show at Paris Fashion Week.
content: Sarah Burton, the fashion designer who took over the namesake label of Lee Alexander McQueen months after his death in 2010, and who created the gown worn by Princess Catherine at her wedding to Prince William a year later, is leaving the brand, its parent company, Kering, said in a statement released Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BMW Says It Will Invest $750 Million to Build Electric Minis in Oxford
description: The move is a boost for Britain’s car industry, but uncertainty remains about the sector’s future in the country.
content: BMW said on Monday that it would invest 600 million pounds, or about $750 million, to build electric versions of its popular Mini car models in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susanne Masters
title: Cool Water and a Slow Pace on Florida’s ‘Spring Runs’
description: Underground springs create short, clear creeks in the state’s interior, and a paddle board is the perfect way to explore them.
content: “That sounds like a baby gator. Did you hear it?” We stopped paddling and listened. Leaves rustled, there was the splash of a turtle sliding into water, and then “pew, pew,” the dainty call of a baby alligator sounding like a video game laser. We saw the hatchling’s mother hauled out on muddy ground. She watched us pass. Giving due deference we moved away, quietly thrilled by the encounter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Reich
title: The Ins, Outs, Ups and Downs of One Woman’s 12-Year Amazon Career
description: In her new memoir, “Exit Interview,” Kristi Coulter details her time working at the company, connecting her experience to the larger history of women’s employment struggles.
content: In 2023, it’s hard to imagine anyone who doesn’t have an opinion about Amazon or is unfamiliar with its treatment of its employees. Through the stories that have come out, it’s easy to form a picture of the company, but what about the people who make up the organization? Why would anyone work there? That picture is missing a face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: We Need Shopping Malls, or Something Like Them
description: Despite my deep conviction that conspicuous consumption is one of the many reasons our planet is in terrible trouble, I have come to love the mall.
content: It was already hot at 5:45 in the morning, the humidity so thick it left me breathless. Even for the South, this was extreme: frog-strangling humidity, smother-you-in-your-sleep heat. It blanketed the region, day after day after day. At one point the forecast called for a heat index here in Nashville that was higher than the heat index in Las Vegas. If you spend much time outdoors in heat like that, it might kill you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: The Tissue That Connects Our Muscles May Be a Key to Better Health
description: Fascia is more important than previously thought. Here’s how, and why, you should care for yours.
content: In recent years, the concept of caring for one’s fascia — the tough, flexible tissue that surrounds and connects muscles, bones and organs like cling wrap — has permeated fitness and wellness culture. Pilates instructors and massage therapists offer to make fascia more supple, and products like foam rollers, massage guns and “fascia blasters” claim to help you improve your fascia health at home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Child Care Is a Strain for Most in New York City
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 11, 2023.
content: “This industry is going to die. We cannot survive without the parents, and the parents cannot survive without us. We’re a unit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Review: Boris Charmatz Unveils a Different Tanztheater Wuppertal
description: Charmatz’s first new work for the company founded by Pina Bausch was a messy, meandering grab-bag of ideas and inspirations.
content: Everyone needs an editor. Writers, directors, cooks, choreographers and designers all need a ruthless eye — internal or external — for their work to find its form; the sculpture within the block of stone. You might even define a great artist by the ability to pitilessly remove the inessential, no matter how clever the sentence or brilliant the movement composition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Andrew Faulk
title: The Big City Where Housing Is Still Affordable
description: Tokyo has succeeded in maintaining an abundance of affordable housing because it has no downtown, many railroads and laws that make it easy to build.
content: Yuta Yamasaki and his wife moved from southern Japan to Tokyo a decade ago because job prospects were better in the big city. They now have three sons — ages 10, 8 and 6 — and they are looking for a larger place to live. But Mr. Yamasaki, who runs a gelato shop, and his wife, a child-care worker, aren’t planning to move far. They are confident they can find an affordable three-bedroom apartment in their own neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The F.D.A. Approved New Covid Shots
description: Also, a new biography of Elon Musk. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The F.D.A. gave the green light today to a new round of Covid boosters, the first to be approved since the public health emergency ended in May. The move comes as the Biden administration is preparing a campaign to convince Americans to get immunized, and as Covid cases tick up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Welcome to Wrexham’ and the MTV Video Music Awards
description: The documentary series about a soccer club owned by Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney returns for a second season. And the annual award show airs live.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: 100 Easy Dinner Recipes for Right Now
description: September is overwhelming. These quick, weeknight-friendly dishes aren’t.
content: Oh, September. You are madness. You are back-to-school and back-to-work after August laze and Labor Day. You are crisp new notebooks and backpacks. You are closed-toe shoes. You are calendars cross-referenced, car pools arranged, nut-free lunches assembled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil A. Lewis
title: Robert S. Bennett, Washington’s Go-to Lawyer in a Scandal, Dies at 84
description: He was a robust defender of a host of high-profile clients, including Bill Clinton over the president’s relationship with an intern.
content: Robert S. Bennett, one of the nation’s leading criminal defense lawyers, who was known for his representation of the powerful and celebrated caught up in scandals, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden Marks 9/11 Anniversary With a Message of Unity
description: “It shouldn’t take a national tragedy to remind us of the power of national unity,” President Biden said.
content: President Biden marked the 22nd anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Monday with a message of unity, saying Americans must protect democratic ideals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Manhattan Judge May Be Open to Moving Trump Trial Date as Cases Mount
description: The judge, Juan M. Merchan, said in a letter that while he was not yet ready to discuss potential changes to the March 25, 2024, trial date, he would be willing to have the conversation in February.
content: The judge presiding over the criminal case against Donald J. Trump in Manhattan signaled that he could be open to changing the date of the trial — now set for March 2024 — in light of the handful of other potential trials the former president now faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: When New York Was ‘Drop Dead City’
description: A documentary about the city’s fiscal crisis of the 1970s, co-directed by the son of one of its saviors, wins the Library of Congress Lavine/Ken Burns Prize for Film.
content: On Oct. 29, 1975, Mike O’Neill, the editor of The Daily News, and Bill Brink, the managing editor, returned from lunch and asked whether President Gerald R. Ford, while addressing the National Press Club in Washington, had agreed to help New York City avoid bankruptcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: 50 Years After a Plane Crash, Their Grief Still Resonates
description: In 1973, Delta Flight 723 went down in Boston, killing 89 people. Fifty years later, the family members left behind found solace in one another.
content: In February 2021, Ellen Barry, a Boston-based reporter who covers mental health for The New York Times, came across an article in Seven Days, a Vermont weekly newspaper, that piqued her interest. The piece focused on Michelle Brennen, who was 10 years old when her father died in a plane crash that had occurred nearly 50 years earlier. On a foggy day in 1973, Delta Flight 723 collided into a sea wall that separated Boston Harbor from Logan International Airport, killing all 89 people on board. Ms. Brennen, the article reported, was searching for family members of those who had died; she wanted to bring them together for a memorial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Some Things Are More Important Than History
description: As a no-hitter stretched into extra innings, a journalist rooted for something extraordinary while his son just wanted the Yankees to win. They both got what they wanted.
content: He didn’t care that it was a no-hitter. He just wanted the Yankees to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen and Amanda Holpuch
title: Ian Wilmut, Scientist Behind Dolly the Cloned Sheep, Is Dead at 79
description: He led a project in Scotland that, in 1996, cloned a mammal for the first time, a feat of genetic engineering that shocked the world.
content: Ian Wilmut, the British scientist who led the project that cloned a mammal for the first time, Dolly the sheep, shocking scientists who had thought that such a procedure was impossible, died on Sunday. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Theaters of War That Make Up the Fighting in Ukraine
description: A “striking fist” in the North, and river crossings in the South. Along a jagged 1,000-mile front, the fighting is multifaceted — and relentless.
content: Along the southern reaches of the Dnipro River, Ukrainian forces are staging amphibious assaults on Russian positions across the river from around the city of Kherson, forcing Russia to deploy already-stretched units to prevent Ukraine from gaining a foothold on the eastern bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Seeks Recusal of Judge in Federal Elections Case
description: The former president said Judge Tanya S. Chutkan, who is hearing the Justice Department’s case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election, had shown bias against him in public statements.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Monday asked the federal judge overseeing his looming trial on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election to recuse herself, claiming that she has shown a bias against Mr. Trump in public statements made from the bench in other cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hussein Ibish
title: Why Is the Biden Administration Working So Hard on a Saudi-Israel Deal?
description: Washington is pushing for ties between the two countries, with a promise of security guarantees for Riyadh.
content: The Biden administration is working overtime to consolidate what is arguably Washington’s most significant advantage over its great power rivals, especially China. That advantage lies in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
title: Aid Trickles In to Moroccans Stranded by Quake, but Desperation Mounts
description: The government defended its response to the earthquake as robust, but some residents desperate for basic supplies say they feel abandoned.
content: Government rescue workers began to reach some devastated mountain villages in Morocco on Monday, but many more settlements were waiting desperately for help, three days after the country was hit by the strongest earthquake in the area in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Cuomo Wins Book Lawsuit, Leaving New York’s Ethics Panel in Limbo
description: A state judge sided with former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s argument that a new state ethics commission was created in a way that violated the State Constitution.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s legal fight to preserve the proceeds of a $5.1 million book deal took a stunning turn on Monday when a state judge essentially invalidated New York’s new ethics commission, which was investigating the book deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: The 343 Reasons a Small Town in Ireland Mourns on Sept. 11
description: Kinsale, an Irish fishing village, is home to a 9/11 memorial honoring the firefighters who were killed in New York that day.
content: Beyond the multicolored shops, red brick streets packed with performers and quays filled with sailboats that draw visitors to the town of Kinsale, County Cork, is a memorial to a tragedy that occurred an ocean away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Olivia Natt, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Shannon Lin, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: U.S. v. Google
description: The government has set its sights on the internet behemoth in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.
content: For years, the government has been trying to rein in Big Tech, pursuing some of the largest and most powerful companies on the internet. This week, the government takes on Google in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Don’t Expect a ‘Theory of Everything’ to Explain It All
description: Not even the most advanced physics can reveal everything we want to know about the history and future of the cosmos, or about ourselves.
content: What good are the laws of physics if we can’t solve the equations that describe them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Treating Overdoses Over the Counter
description: It is now easier than ever to get a medication that stops overdoses.
content: America’s overdose crisis has prompted a significant shift in the war on drugs. Just last week, Narcan, a medication that stops opioid overdoses, became available nationwide without a prescription for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Demonizing Social Media Isn’t the Answer to Online Safety, a New Book Argues
description: One expert says parents should emphasize the importance of digital literacy and privacy, but bans and heavy surveillance don’t work.
content: Panic over social media has reached a fever pitch. Diagnoses of mental illness among adolescents have been on the rise, and in May the U.S. surgeon general warned of “ample indicators” that social media may in part be to blame. In June, a psychologist called for a nationwide ban of cellphones in schools. By next March, kids under 18 in Utah will be allowed to use TikTok and Instagram only if they have explicit parental permission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: In ‘The Other Black Girl,’ the Call Is Coming From Inside the Cubicle
description: This satirical workplace thriller tracks the plight of an assistant as she endures terrors both mysterious and banal.
content: The loneliness, anxiety and discomfort that often comes with being the only Black person in a predominantly white space can turn any office into a mental and emotional minefield. But what if finally gaining a new Black co-worker only made matters worse?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nada Rashwan and Aida Alami
title: The Moroccan government defends its quake response, but the king is little in evidence.
description: King Mohammed VI waited hours before making his first public statement on the disaster, and has made few since. It was a government spokesman who pushed back on Monday against growing criticism on the pace of rescue efforts.
content: As public criticism mounted over the pace and efficiency of Morocco’s earthquake response, King Mohammed VI’s government issued its first public defense of the operation on Monday, saying the authorities had promptly addressed the disaster and were dedicating their efforts to rescue operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Palm Fronds and Car Parts: Assemblage Art in Los Angeles
description: The Hammer Museum’s biennial showcases several artists steeped in the scrappy art form, now flourishing in the city.
content: A decade ago, priced out of renting an apartment and studio in Los Angeles, the artist Dominique Moody built a steel-clad, wood structure on a 20-foot flatbed trailer. It was an experiment in making a small, mobile abode before the tiny home trend took off. It offered a place to sleep, and dream. It was also in many ways an artwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Jimmy Buffett’s Hits Album Reaches the Top 10 After His Death
description: The new LP by the singer-songwriter Zach Bryan holds at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, after a ticket sale for his new tour and the musician’s arrest in Oklahoma.
content: The singer-songwriter Zach Bryan repeats at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, while a nearly 40-year-old compilation by Jimmy Buffett rockets into the Top 10 following his death on Sept. 1, at 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Twinkies and Jam to Mix as Smucker Buys Hostess for $5.6 Billion
description: J.M. Smucker, the maker of jellies, Jif peanut butter and Uncrustables, agreed to take over Hostess Brands, adding Twinkies, Ho Hos and Ding Dongs to its portfolio of snacks.
content: In a sugary union of major snack makers, J.M. Smucker, known for its jellies, Jif peanut butter and many other brands, agreed to acquire Hostess Brands, the maker of Twinkies, Ho Hos and Ding Dongs, in a deal worth $5.6 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Aftermath of the Earthquake in Morocco, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Her Choice: Love, or the Lease on a Beloved Studio. It Took Some Thought.
description: Taking guidance from a favorite childhood novel, “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,” a woman says she had to decide what kind of a person she wanted to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Special Ops: Lioness’ Reconsidered
description: Taylor Sheridan’s latest series for Paramount+ deserved a longer look.
content: Contains spoilers for the recently concluded first season of “Special Ops: Lioness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Jackie Frere
title: Getting to Genius, Part 1: Spelling Bee for Beginners
description: Two Games editors take you through the best ways to move up the ranks.
content: This is Part 1 of a two-part series on learning to solve Spelling Bee. Be sure to check out Part 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Videos of ‘Earthquake Lights’ Above Morocco Are an Unexplained Mystery.
description: Sightings of aerial luminous phenomena, often observed during earthquakes, are being shared online. Experts aren’t sure what causes them.
content: People near Marrakesh, Morocco, shared videos recorded before the 6.8-magnitude earthquake that hit the area last Friday, showing unidentified lights in the sky. The bizarre aerial phenomena are known as earthquake lights, and seem to occur above sites of seismic stress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: A New N.B.A. Champion’s Takeaway From a U.F.C. Champ: Relax
description: Denver Nuggets guard Jamal Murray’s friendship with Alexander Volkanovski, the U.F.C. featherweight champion, is changing his approach to winning.
content: It was a Sunday afternoon in early July, and Jamal Murray had been in Las Vegas for a few days — enough time for the city to wear out anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Trump Is Really Old, Too
description: Why is Joe Biden’s age a bigger issue than the former president’s?
content: To our intensifying discussion about whether President Biden has grown mentally fuzzy and too old for a second term, I’d like to add this question: How would we even notice Donald Trump’s lapse into incoherence, when derangement is essentially his brand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Investors Warily Await the Instacart and Arm I.P.O.s
description: The valuations for both companies have come in below expectations, reflecting a cautious outlook on Wall Street as firms start to go public again after a fallow patch.
content: Instacart just published the latest prospectus for its initial public offering, with the grocery delivery company aiming for a valuation of up to $9.3 billion when it prices its shares as soon as next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Moises Saman
title: ‘Wounds Will Need to Be Healed’: Collisions in a Fractured Israel
description: Israelis are deeply split about what kind of country Israel should be. Four encounters at four recent protests show how that division plays out in daily life.
content: When Ana Lavi neared the gates of her village in southern Israel late one night in July, a small group of men appeared in the road, surrounded her car and blocked its path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: As Covid-19 Cases Tick Higher, Conspiracy Theorists Stoke New Fears
description: A late-summer rise in Covid-19 infections is bringing with it a wave of conspiracy theories.
content: As Covid-19 cases have climbed as part of a late-summer uptick, right-wing influencers and conspiracy theorists have responded by stoking fears about mass lockdowns and spreading unsubstantiated new ideas about Covid-19’s links to world events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: Escapee Had Been a Fugitive Before Pennsylvania Jailbreak
description: The subject of the manhunt outside Philadelphia disappeared into the wilderness in 2017 after an arrest warrant was issued in connection with a murder in northern Brazil.
content: It was just after midnight on a Saturday. A light rain was starting to fall in the mostly empty town square by the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Aida Alami, Yassine Oulhiq and Sergey Ponomarev
title: Fury as Quake Help Finally Arrives: ‘How Many Hours Has It Been?’
description: The people of a village high in the Atlas Mountains erupted in anger when the Moroccan government left them alone for three days to dig out and bury their loved ones.
content: When the earth seized his house and shook it late Friday night, Mohamed Abarada ran outside with his 9-month-old daughter in his arms. His mother, his wife and his 9-year-old daughter were still inside, trapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: When Does a Style Become a Classic?
description: In a sea of trends, a reader wonders how to identify a timeless clothing item.
content: “Classic” is one of those words everyone throws around but almost no one defines. Most people’s attitudes toward identifying classics seem to mirror Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart’s, well, classic, words about pornography in Jacobellis v. Ohio: “I know it when I see it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Aaron Rodgers’s Favorite Receiver Is Also the Jets’ Messenger
description: Randall Cobb spent a decade catching Rodgers’s passes in Green Bay. He’s using that experience to teach young Jets receivers about their new quarterback’s tendencies.
content: On the day the Jets traded for quarterback Aaron Rodgers in April, Randall Cobb posted a workout video to Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy
title: 50 Years Ago, a Bloody Coup Ended Democracy in Chile
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet led the violent overthrow of the socialist government of Salvador Allende, seizing power for nearly 17 years. Here is a selection of photographs from the coup and its aftermath.
content: Fifty years ago on Monday, a violent coup ended one of Latin America’s most stable democracies, brought an abrupt halt to the Chilean military’s tradition of noninvolvement in politics and ushered in 17 years of ruthless dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Mimi Leder Believes in Big Feelings
description: In an interview, the veteran director discussed her career and her work on “The Morning Show,” returning Wednesday for its third season on Apple TV+.
content: Mimi Leder wasn’t born with a camera in her hand. But it didn’t take her long to pick one up. Her father was Paul Leder, an auteur of, in her words, “ultra ultra low-budget films.” She and her two siblings worked on them — shooting, writing, editing, more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Alfredo Martinez, Who Fused Art World and Underworld, Dies at 56
description: He created hoopla around art made in prison — first in the early 2000s, with himself as the artist, then 20 years later with the scammer Anna Sorokin.
content: Alfredo Martinez lived on New York City’s margins, a squatter who shook off one eviction after another. He was an artist who usually lacked a gallery and sometimes  put on exhibits in a storage locker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: abstention

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K.’s Arrest of Suspected Spy Fuels Calls for Tougher Stance on China
description: Allegations that a researcher in Parliament was a foreign agent have intensified a fiery debate over Britain’s relations with Beijing.
content: Even by the prolific standards of China’s foreign influence operations, it would represent a sensational case of infiltration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Recent Screen Adaptations of Popular Y.A. Novels?
description: Fantasy, romance and adventure novels written for young adults have long been the basis for movies and television shows. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.
content: Fantasy, romance and adventure novels written for young adults have long been the basis for movies and television shows. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.

author: By Aatish Bhatia and Claire Cain Miller
title: Explore How Income Influences Attendance at 139 Top Colleges
description: Unlike many elite colleges, most flagship public colleges are “pretty fair in who gets in.”
content: Unlike many elite colleges, most flagship public colleges are “pretty fair in who gets in.”

title: Remembering 9/11 on the Trail
description: How politicians have navigated their campaigns around Sept. 11 tributes.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Rescuers From Spain Search for Survivors in Morocco
description: Spanish rescue teams aided Moroccan crews in searching for victims of the powerful earthquake that devastated the country.
content: Spanish rescue teams aided Moroccan crews in searching for victims of the powerful earthquake that devastated the country.
